7.passage:
He passed away just as you rode up on your bike."

"Yes, that is so," said [MASK]. "Imagine us both as addressing you from another and a happier world.

12.passage:
Well, look at my own experience this morning."

"I only contend that it is possible in England," replied [MASK], who had been to that country long ago, before the big rush, and had received a cordial welcome at Cambridge.

"It is impossible here.

17.passage:
All are exactly alike. Do you not agree with me?"

"I do not," replied [MASK], entering into the bitter fun, and feeling both pain and amusement at each word that was uttered. "For my own part I find such profound differences among our rulers.

32.passage: "So have I," said [MASK], unexpectedly veering. "All ladies are far from alike." Their mood was changed, and they recalled little kindnesses and courtesies.

39.passage:
Respectful but irritated, he answered, "Once is enough."

"Yes, he has done his duty," said [MASK]. "Do not tease him so.

44.passage: Wedlock, motherhood, power in the house   for what else is she born, and how can the man who has denied them to her stand up to face her creator and his own at the last day? [MASK] took his leave saying "Perhaps . . . but later . . ."    his invariable reply to such an appeal.

46.passage: You mustn't put off what you think right," said [MASK]. "That is why India is in such a plight, because we put off things." But seeing that his young relative looked worried, he added a few soothing words, and thus wiped out any impression that his wife might have made.

51.passage:
He has found out our dinner hour, that's all, and chooses to interrupt us every time, in order to show his power."

"On the one hand he always does this, on the other it may be a serious case, and you cannot know," said [MASK], considerately paving the way towards obedience. "Had you not better clean your teeth after pan?"

"If my teeth are to be cleaned, I don't go at all.

61.passage:
O Tonga wallah, club, club. Why doesn't the fool go?"

"Go, I will pay you to-morrow," said [MASK] to the driver, and as they went off he called courteously, "You are most welcome, ladies." They did not reply, being full of their own affairs.

65.passage: He began: "Dear Sir,   At your express command I have hastened as a subordinate should      " and then stopped. "Tell him I have called, that is sufficient," [MASK] said, tearing the protest up. "Here is my card.

69.passage: "Then telephone for one down to the railway station." And since the man hastened to do this [MASK] said, "Enough, enough, I prefer to walk." He commandeered a match and lit a cigarette.

70.passage:
Another pillar moved, a third, and then an Englishwoman stepped out into the moonlight. Suddenly [MASK] was furiously angry and shouted: "Madam! Madam! Madam!"

"Oh! Oh!" the woman gasped.

95.passage:
She exclaimed; she had forgotten the snakes.

"For example, a six-spot beetle," [MASK] continued, "You pick it up, it bites, you die."

"But you walk about yourself.

121.passage:
She sighed and rose to go.

"Would you care to see over the Minto Hospital one morning?" [MASK] enquired. "I have nothing else to offer at Chandrapore.

132.passage:
You understand me, you know what others feel. Oh, if others resembled you!"

Rather surprised, [MASK] replied: "I don't think I understand people very well. I only know whether I like or dislike them."

"Then you are an Oriental.

140.passage:
"The angle would have altered   she rises later."

"Later and later," yawned [MASK], who was tired after her walk. "Let me think   we don't see the other side of the moon out here, no."

"Come, India's not as bad as all that," said a pleasant voice.

156.passage:
I've avoided," said [MASK]. "Excepting my own servant, I've scarcely spoken to an Indian since landing."

"Oh, lucky you.

They give me the creeps."

173.passage:
"I'm tired of seeing picturesque figures pass before me as a frieze," [MASK] explained. "It was wonderful when we landed, but that superficial glamour soon goes."

Her impressions were of no interest to the Collector; he was only concerned to give her a good time.

175.passage:
I only want those Indians whom you come across socially   as your friends."

"Well, we don't come across them socially," [MASK] said, laughing. "They're full of all the virtues, but we don't, and it's now eleven-thirty, and too late to go into the reasons.

184.passage:
I prefer my smoke at the club amongst my own sort, I'm afraid."

"Why not ask the Pleaders to the club?" [MASK] persisted.

190.passage:
"But, mother, you can't do that sort of thing."

"Can't mother?" [MASK] replied.

"No, really not in this country.

She paused, then said emphatically: "Very nice."

"Who was he?" [MASK] enquired.

204.passage:
He said he wasn't allowed to."

Thereupon the truth struck him, and [MASK] cried "Oh, good gracious! Not a Mohammedan? Why ever didn't you tell me you'd been talking to a native? I was going all wrong."

"A Mohammedan!

209.passage:
I wish you had had them on."

"I think it was impudence, but I don't know about a trick," said [MASK]. "His nerves were all on edge   I could tell from his voice.

212.passage:
"You oughtn't to have answered."

"Now look here," said [MASK], "wouldn't you expect a Mohammedan to answer if you asked him to take off his hat in church?"

"It's different, it's different; you don't understand.

219.passage: The young people glanced at each other and smiled; it amused them when the old lady got these gentle creeps, and harmony was restored between them consequently. [MASK] continued: "What a terrible river! what a wonderful river!" and sighed. The radiance was already altering, whether through shifting of the moon or of the sand; soon the bright sheaf would be gone, and a circlet, itself to alter, be burnished upon the streaming void.

222.passage:
Did you gather he was well disposed?"

Ignorant of the force of this question, [MASK] replied, "Yes, quite, after the first moment."

"I meant, generally.

243.passage:
She is very, very fair-minded."

"I know," [MASK] said dejectedly.

The note of anxiety in his voice made her feel that he was still a little boy, who must have what he liked, so she promised to do as he wished, and they kissed good night.

244.passage:
There he clung, asleep, while jackals in the plain bayed their desires and mingled with the percussion of drums.

"Pretty dear," said [MASK] to the wasp. He did not wake, but her voice floated out, to swell the night's uneasiness.

But they come too seldom and live too far away. Meanwhile      "

Her husband made her give purdah parties until she struck."

"Oh, really," was the haughty rejoinder.

Oh, really," was the haughty rejoinder.

"You're superior to them, anyway.

Oh yes, they're English-speaking."

She knows Paris also," called one of the onlookers.

"They pass Paris on the way, no doubt," said [MASK], as if she was describing the movements of migratory birds. Her manner had grown more distant since she had discovered that some of the group was Westernized, and might apply her own standards to her.

301.passage:
She added, "We leave for Calcutta to-day."

"Oh, do you?" said [MASK], not at first seeing the implication. Then she cried, "Oh, but if you do we shall find you gone.

Accustomed to the privacy of London, she could not realize that India, seemingly so mysterious, contains none, and that consequently the conventions have greater force. "I suppose nothing's on her mind," [MASK] continued.

"Ask her, ask her yourself, my dear boy.

345.passage:
A side-issue, a side-issue?" [MASK] repeated. "How can it be that?"

"We're not out here for the purpose of behaving pleasantly!"

"What do you mean?"

"What I say. We're out here to do justice and keep the peace.

349.passage:
India isn't a drawing-room."

"Your sentiments are those of a god," [MASK] said quietly, but it was his manner rather than his sentiments that annoyed her.

Trying to recover his temper, he said, "India likes gods.

354.passage:
One touch of regret   not the canny substitute but the true regret from the heart   would have made him a different man, and the British Empire a different institution.

"I'm going to argue, and indeed dictate," [MASK] said, clinking her rings. "The English are out here to be pleasant.

356.passage:
The English are out here to be pleasant."

"How do you make that out, mother?" [MASK] asked, speaking gently again, for he was ashamed of his irritability.

"Because India is part of the earth.

374.passage: He gazed at it, and tears spouted from his eyes. [MASK] thought, "How unhappy I am!" But because he really was unhappy, another emotion soon mingled with his self-pity: he desired to remember his wife and could not.

"Come in with it if you don't mind the unconventionality.

the shirt back's hole is rather small and to rip it wider a pity."

"We wear them to pass the Police.

"There honestly is none," [MASK] replied. "We are by nature a most informal people.

462.passage:
We are by nature a most informal people."

"I wouldn't worry about that.

"That's a notion," said the other man.

"We English do.

"A mystery is a muddle.

Why not settle altogether in India?"

Visitors like you are too rare."

"They are indeed," said [MASK]. "Such affability is seldom seen.

502.passage:
You can make India in England apparently, just as you can make England in India."

"Frightfully expensive in both cases," said [MASK].

"I suppose so."

What was he to do? "Yes, all that is settled," [MASK] cried.

"I invite you all to see me in the Marabar Caves.

I've not even heard of them."

"Then tell me everything you will, or I shall never understand India.

"No, not large.

523.passage:
My dear young sir, the pot and the kettle! Have you ever heard of that useful proverb?"

"No, not large.

and I'll tell you about it."

He isn't a bounder," protested [MASK]. "His nerves are on edge, that's all."

He was all right when I left."

"Well, it's nothing I've said," said [MASK] reassuringly. "I never even spoke to him.

578.passage:
It's a shame we never heard you sing."

"I may sing now," [MASK] replied, and did.

His thin voice rose, and gave out one sound after another.

579.passage:
The sounds continued and ceased after a few moments as casually as they had begun   apparently half through a bar, and upon the subdominant.

"Thanks so much: what was that?" asked [MASK].

"I will explain in detail.

590.passage:
The Marabar Caves."

"Well, I'm blessed," [MASK] murmured after a pause. "Did he descend to any details?"

"He did not.

I prefer to rest."

If you want to go to the Marabar Caves, you'll go under British auspices."

The young people were ashamed.

612.passage:
"My temper's rotten, I must apologize," was [MASK] reply. "I didn't mean to order you and mother about, but of course the way those Bengalis let you down this morning annoyed me, and I don't want that sort of thing to keep happening."

"It's nothing to do with them that I . . .

618.passage:
It seemed slipping away like a dream. [MASK] said, "But let us discuss things; it's all so frightfully important, we mustn't make false steps. I want next to hear your point of view about me   it might help us both."

His manner was unhappy and reserved.

622.passage:
He felt angry and bruised; he was too proud to tempt her back, but he did not consider that she had behaved badly, because where his compatriots were concerned he had a generous mind.

"I suppose that there is nothing else; it's unpardonable of me to have given you and your mother all this bother," said [MASK] heavily, and frowned up at the tree beneath which they were sitting. A little green bird was observing her, so brilliant and neat that it might have hopped straight out of a shop.

623.passage: Some Indian wild bird. "Yes, nothing else," [MASK] repeated, feeling that a profound and passionate speech ought to have been delivered by one or both of them. "We've been awfully British over it, but I suppose that's all right.

631.passage: Of course they were friends, and for ever. "Do you know what the name of that green bird up above us is?" [MASK] asked, putting her shoulder rather nearer to his.

639.passage:
"So am I. I'm useless at everything."

"What do I hear?" shouted [MASK] at the top of his voice, causing both of them to start. "What most improbable statement have I heard?

643.passage:
I have, sahib, I have."

"How do you do?" said [MASK], likewise pulling herself together. She held out her hand.

I think perhaps I ought to see your mother and discuss future plans."

"He may show you some aspect of the country I can't, and he's a real loyalist.

652.passage: Despite my advanced years, I am learning to drive," [MASK] said. "Man can learn everything if he will but try." And foreseeing a further difficulty, he added, "I do not do the actual steering.

654.passage:
He cried out in Arabic, and violently tugged his beard.

"What's the damage?" enquired [MASK], after the moment's pause that he permitted himself before taking charge of a situation. The Eurasian, inclined to be flustered, rallied to the sound of his voice, and, every inch an Englishman, replied, "You give me five minutes' time, I'll take you any dam anywhere.

660.passage:
Well, it's all over now, tears are useless," said [MASK], dismounting. "We had some luck butting that tree."

"All over . . .

We skidded."

699.passage:
No more."

Here I am, stuck in dam India same as you, and you got to fit me in better than this."

704.passage: Her Maharajah would be awfully sick, but she didn't mind, he could sack her if he liked. "I don't believe in these people letting you down," [MASK] said. "If I didn't snatch like the devil, I should be nowhere.

They're priceless."

yet I cannot imagine that they have been as successful as British India, where we see reason and orderliness spreading in every direction, like a most health-giving flood!"

[MASK] said "Golly!"

Undeterred by the expletive, the old man swept on. His tongue had been loosed and his mind had several points to make.

Our excellent host awoke much rattled from his dreams, appeared to think it was our fault, and chanted exactly, exactly."

Get well quickly, for I do not know what our little circle would do without you."

So we go on, and so we shall continue to go, I think, until the end of time."

"Anyhow, you want to rest.

"But you haven't children.

But I can't marry her if I wanted to, for she has just become engaged to the City Magistrate."

He recovered himself at once and laughed, but her error broke up their conversation   their civilization it had almost been   which scattered like the petals of a desert flower, and left them in the middle of the hills.

1101.passage: En route_ for these, they encountered several isolated caves, which the guide persuaded them to visit, but really there was nothing to see; they lit a match, admired its reflection in the polish, tested the echo and came out again. [MASK] was "pretty sure they should come on some interesting old carvings soon," but only meant he wished there were some carvings. His deeper thoughts were about the breakfast.

Luckily, each had abundance of common sense and good will.

1107.passage:
Yes, indeed, do come and see my wife"   for he felt it more artistic to have his wife alive for a moment.

1110.passage:
She is not in Chandrapore just now."

"And have you children?"

"Are they a great pleasure to you?"

"Why, naturally, I adore them," he laughed.

1115.passage: He was in trouble how to conceal his confusion. "One, one in my own particular case," [MASK] sputtered, and let go of her hand. Quite a number of caves were at the top of the track, and thinking, "Damn the English even at their best," he plunged into one of them to recover his balance.

1119.passage:
Which cave?"

1124.passage: The man fled, and he was left alone. [MASK] thought, "This is the end of my career, my guest is lost." And then he discovered the simple and sufficient explanation of the mystery.

1140.passage:

1154.passage: Before breakfast was over, he had told a good many lies. "She ran to her friend, I to mine," [MASK] went on, smiling. "And now I am with my friends and they are with me and each other, which is happiness.

1169.passage:
"Then the guide came back to you?"

"Exactly. Got a cigarette?"

"Poetry," [MASK] said, with tears in his eyes. "Let us discuss why poetry has lost the power of making men brave.

2204.passage:
My carriage fetched you   let it take you away."

2218.passage: he and she are, after all, both members of another race." "Where are my twenty thousand rupees?" [MASK] thought. He was absolutely indifferent to money   not merely generous with it, but promptly paying his debts when he could remember to do so   yet these rupees haunted his mind, because he had been tricked about them, and allowed them to escape overseas, like so much of the wealth of India.

2223.passage: But each according to his own capacities, and he knew that his own were small. "One old Englishwoman and one little, little wasp," [MASK] thought, as he stepped out of the temple into the grey of a pouring wet morning. "It does not seem much, still it is more than I am myself.

2225.passage: As he returned to his house   which stood in a pleasant garden further up the main street of the town   he could see his old patron paddling and capering in the slush ahead. "Hullo!" [MASK] called, and it was the wrong remark, for the devotee indicated by circular gestures of his arms that he did not desire to be disturbed.

2227.passage:
he called, and it was the wrong remark, for the devotee indicated by circular gestures of his arms that he did not desire to be disturbed. He added, "Sorry," which was right, for [MASK] twisted his head till it didn't belong to his body, and said in a strained voice that had no connection with his mind: "He arrived at the European Guest House perhaps   at least possibly."

"Did he? Since when?"

But time was too definite.

2235.passage: Presently they intersected a line of prisoners, who were looking aimlessly at an old bronze gun. "Which of you is to be pardoned?" [MASK] asked. For to-night was the procession of the Chief God, when He would leave the palace, escorted by the whole power of the State, and pass by the Jail, which stood down in the town now.

2236.passage:
They did not distinguish between the God and the Rajah in their minds, both were too far above them; but the guard was better educated, and ventured to enquire after His Highness's health.

"It always improves," replied the medicine man. As a matter of fact, [MASK] was dead, the ceremony overnight had overtaxed his strength.

2240.passage:

2244.passage:

"Not the least.

2246.passage:
I heard you were settled in there."

"Why have you not answered my letters?" [MASK] asked, going straight for the point, but not reaching it, owing to buckets of rain. His companion, new to the country, cried, as the drops drummed on his topi, that the bees were renewing their attack.

"How much do you make out of yours?"

"His Highness's Private Secretary, probably.

2351.passage:

"There is still the procession."
